title-group.subtitle: Evaluating Cell Identity in Advanced In Vitro Kidney Models

related-article.article-title: Comparative Analysis of Human Kidney Organoid and Tubuloid Models

body.p: Kidney organoids and tubuloids have become invaluable tools in kidney research over the past decade. Despite their shared application in studying (patho)physiology, drug testing, and potential therapeutic use in bioartificial and bioengineered kidneys, they exhibit fundamental differences. Kidney organoids, typically derived from induced pluripotent stem cells, autonomously self-organize into early nephron structures, mirroring aspects of embryonic kidney development. Conversely, tubuloids originate from mature kidney tubule cells and more closely mimic the behavior of adult tubule cells during turnover and regeneration. Multiple protocols for culturing organoids and tubuloids have been developed, and in this issue of Kidney360, Nunez-Nescolarde et al.1 systematically analyze and compare bulk gene expression patterns from four different protocols. Their study aims to assess the suitability of these models for specific applications by evaluating nephron segment-specific genes and those linked to ischemic and hereditary kidney diseases.

The study compares organoids generated through the Takasato protocol with tubuloids derived from three sources: fetal kidney cells, adult kidney cells, and induced pluripotent stem cell organoid-derived cells (referred to as iTubuloids). As expected, organoids contain not only tubular epithelial cells but also nonepithelial renal and even nonrenal off-target cells. Proximal tubule markers were expressed at higher levels in organoid cultures, whereas tubuloids showed higher levels of collecting duct-specific markers. Moreover, adult kidney-derived tubuloids exhibit a more mature metabolism as well as activation of inflammatory and aging pathways. These traits, combined with greater interdonor gene expression variability, suggest that adult tubuloids may better represent the biologic complexity of adult patients, factoring in both genetic background and acquired influences such as aging and inflammation.

The authors propose that organoids and tubuloids can serve as effective models for studying genetic kidney diseases, as nearly three-quarters of congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract (CAKUT)–associated genes are expressed in one or more models. Furthermore, by exposing iTubuloids to repeated ischemic injury, they observe activation of acute damage and profibrotic pathways, maladaptive repair, and apoptosis, suggesting the applicability of these models for investigating ischemic damage.

Although gene expression patterns align well with established literature, Nunez-Nescolarde et al.1 stand among the first to meticulously compare gene expression profiles across multiple kidney culture systems. However, recent advancements have led to additional culture protocols for both organoids and tubuloids. For instance, organoid systems have been developed that enable differentiation toward collecting duct cells, and newer tubuloid cultures allow for enhanced differentiation toward a proximal tubule phenotype and phenotypes of the distal nephron segments.2–5

At its core, this study is about cell identity—a concept far more complex than the mere expression of select genes. Cell identity is traditionally defined by lineage, phenotype (physical, molecular, and functional features), and state (dynamic responses to stimuli).6 A single transcription factor, such as GATA3—also present in the skin and parathyroid gland—does not inherently define a collecting duct cell. Similarly, while genetic kidney disease–associated genes may be expressed in organoid and tubuloid models, their presence alone does not ensure these systems serve as reliable disease models. To gain deeper insights into cell identity, single-cell sequencing would offer a finer resolution compared to bulk sequencing. Moreover, additional factors such as protein synthesis, morphology, and functionality warrant consideration.

Organoids and tubuloids are reductionist models that trade biologic complexity for experimental control. This simplification can generate ambiguous phenotypes that do not perfectly align with specific in vivo cell populations (e.g., SLC12A1 expression without UMOD). Nevertheless, the true value of a model lies in its functional relevance to a particular physiologic process rather than its ability to precisely match all in vivo characteristics. This principle extends to bioartificial and bioengineered kidneys, where epithelial function is more crucial than lineage and state. In applied research, functional mimicry often outweighs strict adherence to traditional definitions of cell identity.

The study implicitly highlights the relevance of targeted mimicry over complete replication, as exemplified in disease modeling. For ischemic kidney injury in vivo, current pathophysiologic concepts focus on inflammation, maladaptive repair, apoptosis, and fibrosis in adult tubule cells. The fact that renal epithelial cells in iTubuloids induce these pathways under ischemic conditions suggests their suitability as a model system. Adult tubuloids may offer an even closer representation, given their direct derivation from adult primary tissue. However, considerations differ for models mimicking CAKUT. Gene expression related to CAKUT is only meaningful if the model appropriately captures embryonic development, making organoids a more relevant choice than tubuloids, which primarily mimic adult cell turnover and damage repair.

This study marks a significant advancement in cataloging the characteristics of various organoid and tubuloid models through comparative gene expression profiling. Many genes linked to kidney (patho)physiology are expressed—albeit in model-specific ways. The authors also demonstrate that acute and chronic kidney damage pathways can be activated in response to external stimuli. It is important to recognize that gene expression alone does not validate a system's suitability for disease modeling, just as the presence of a nonphysiologic phenotype does not necessarily undermine a model's relevance for studying (patho)physiology or its potential application in bioengineered or bioartificial kidneys. Taken together, for now, tubuloids and organoids should be viewed as tools, not definitive end points, and their effectiveness must be assessed within the specific context of their intended application.
